etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘graft a bud or shoot into a different plant’): from Latin inoculat- ‘engrafted’, from the verb inoculare, from in- ‘into’ + oculus ‘eye, bud’. The sense ‘vaccinate’ dates from the early 18th century

definitions: immunize (someone) against a disease by introducing infective material, microorganisms, or vaccine into the body

examples.text: he inoculated his tenants against smallpox

definitions: introduce (an infective agent) into an organism

examples.text: the microorganism can be inoculated into laboratory animals

definitions: introduce (cells or organisms) into a culture medium

examples.text: 0.5 ml of the specimen was inoculated into each tissue culture flask

shortDefinitions: introduce cells or organisms into culture medium
